The claim is supported by Robin Gahan: the director of programs at the Virginia Interfaith Center for Public Policy, who stated that families cannot get by on the current minimum wage of $7.25 an hour.
The claim is based on a December 2013 re: a liberal think tank, which measures the minimum wage over the years against household poverty levels.
In 1968: the minimum wage for most workers was $1.60 an hour, which, when calculated for a full-time worker, would have earned $3,328 annually. This amount was above the poverty thresholds for a three-person household that year.
The current minimum wage of: 7.25 an hour falls slightly below the average 2013 poverty threshold for a family of two, which is $15,156 annually.
